) Each employee in the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is affected in the mance of duties by laws governing the conﬁdentiality of records and information. These laws are collectively referred to as disclosure laws and balance the competing interests of protecting the public’s personal and ﬁnancial privacy while maintaining open and effective administration of ment. These laws establish what information is conﬁdential, who may have access to it and for what purposes, and how employees must account for release of conﬁdential information. These laws also determine what must be made public and, if so, whether the information must be published, made generally available, or made available only upon request. Additionally, these laws restrict the types of personal information gathered and about individuals, and grant certain individuals the right to inspect records. (

Income tax examiners and their managers should thoroughly acquaint them- selves with the examination procedures and information contained in this IRM.
The following table lists commonly used terms and acronyms and their deﬁni- tions used throughout this IRM.

A mathematical technique used to computer score income tax returns as to examination potential. Examination potential is indicated by a numeric score, which is assigned to each return by examination class; the greater the score, the greater the examination potential within each examination class.
Any employee of the IRS including examiners, managers, executives and support staff.

Revenue agents and tax compliance officers/tax auditors located in of the seven SB/SE Field Examination areas, SB/SE Speciality or LB&I, who conduct ﬁeld examinations of income or speciality tax returns ﬁled by individuals, businesses, and other entities to ensure compliance with Federal tax laws.

Bureau of the U.S. Department of the Treasury that provides a modern- ized foundation to better collect, store, safeguard, analyze and share data obtained pursuant to Treasury’s regulatory authority under the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA).
Legislative act that provides for public access to records and informa- tion maintained by Federal agencies.
A SAR is a report made by a ﬁnancial institution to the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, an agency of the United States Depart
ment of the Treasury, regarding suspicious or potentially suspicious activity.
The Office of Disclosure (hereinafter referenced as Disclosure) helps all IRS employees protect conﬁdential tax and other sensitive information.

) Employees may become aware of an unauthorized disclosure and/or tion of records during the course of their examination. Actions to be taken the employee and time frames are as follows: a. Information Loss—All information losses or thefts must be reported one hour. See IRM

, Timely Reporting: Within One Hour. b. Intentional Unauthorized Disclosure—If the employee becomes aware an intentional unauthorized disclosure, the incident must be reported the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) as soon possible. See IRM

, Intentional Unauthorized Disclosures. c.
